content: Puella Diānae corōnam dat quia Diānam amat.

content: The farmer praises the good dinner.
The farmer lives in the small cottage.
The daughter’s good dinner is pleasing to the farmer.

content: His daughter is getting a good dinner for the farmer.
His little daughter lives with the farmer.
Malae fīliae bonās cēnās nōn parant.
answer1: The bad daughters do not prepare good dinners.
answer2: Bad daughters do not prepare good dinners.
answer3: The bad daughters are not preparing good dinners.

answer1: The chickens love the farmer's daughter.
The daughter of the famer is not pleasing to the lady.

content: Cēna est grāta agricolae et agricola bonam fīliam laudat.
answer1: The dinner is pleasing to the farmer and the farmer praises his good daughter.

content: Agricola cum fīliā in casā habitat.
answer1: The farmer lives in the cottage with his daughter.
The good daughter is preparing a good dinner for the farmer.

content: Domina bonae puellae parvae pecūniam dat.
answer1: The lady gives money to the little girl.
The lady lives in a great island.

content: Deinde fīlia agricolae gallīnās ad cēnam vocat.
answer1: Then the daughter calls the chickens to dinner.

content: Suntne tubae novae in meā casā? Nōn sunt.
answer1: Are your new trumpets in my cottage? They are not.

content: Estne Italia lāta terra? Longa est Italia, nōn lāta.
answer1: Is Italia a wide land? Italia is long, not wide.

content: Nautae altās et lātās amant aquās.
answer1: The sailors love deep and open waters.

content: Cui Galba agricola fābulam novam nārrat? Fīliābus dominae clārae fābulam novam nārrat.
answer1: To whom does Galba the farmer tell the story? To the daughters of the famous lady.

content: Quid ancilla tua portat? Ancilla mea tubam novam portat.
answer1: What does your slave girl carry? My slave girl carries a new trumpet.

content: Ubi sunt Lesbia et Iūlia? In tuā casā est Lesbia et Iūlia est in meā.
answer1: Where are Lesbia and Julia? Lesbia and Julia are in your cottage.

content: Quem laudat Lātōna? Lātōna laudat fīliam.
answer1: Who does Latona praise? Latona praises her daughter.

content: Quis lātā in silvā habitat? Diāna, lūnae clārae pulchra dea, lātā in silvā habitat.
answer1: Who lives in the woods? Diana, the beautiful goddess of the clear moon, lives in the broad forest.

content: Ancilla mea, Galba, equō lēgātī aquam et frūmentum dat.
answer1: Galba, my slave girls is giving water and food to the legate.

content: M. Sextus et servus ad mūrum oppidī properant. Oppidānī bellum parant.
answer1: Marcus Sextus and his servant hasten to the city's wall. The townspeople are getting ready for war.

content: Ubi, Mārce, est ancilla tua? Cūr nōn cēnam parat?
answer1: Marcus, where is your slave girl? Why is she not preparing dinner?

content: Quis, Mārce, est lēgātus cum pīlō et tubā?
answer1: Marcus, who is the legate with the javelin and the trumpet?

content: In oppidō Sextus cum fīliābus habitat.
answer1: Sextus lives in a town with his daughters.

content: Amant oppidānī Sextum et laudant, quod magnā cum cōnstantiā pugnat.
answer1: The townspeople love Sextus and prasise him because he fights with great constancy.
What are the townsfolk getting ready for?
What does the slave girl gives to the legate's horse?

content: Quis ad mūrum cum Sextō properat?
answer1: Who hastens to the wall with Sextus?
Whom do the townspeople love and praise?
Whose horse does the slave girl take care of?

content: Cūr nōn servus Sextī equum dominī cūrat?
answer1: Why does Sextus' servant not care for the lord's horse?

content: She is hastening towards Julia, the farmer’s daughter.
My friend is from a village of Germany, my fatherland.
My friend does not love the people of Italy.
Who is caring for the good horse of Galba, the farmer?
answer1: Quis equum bonum Galbae agricolae curat?

content: Wicked slave, who is your friend? Why does he not praise Galba, your master?
answer1: Quis, male serve, est amicus? Cur Galbam dominum non laudat?

content: Mark, where is Lesbia, the maidservant?
Patria servī bonī, vīcus servōrum bonōrum, bone popule.
Populus oppidī magnī, in oppidō magnō, in oppidīs magnīs.
Cum pīlīs longīs, ad pīla longa, ad mūrōs lātōs.
Lēgāte male, amīcī legātī malī, cēna grāta dominō bonō.
Frūmentum equōrum parvōrum, domine bone, ad lēgātōs clārōs.
Rhēnus est in Germāniā, patriā meā.
Oppidānī bonī Sextō lēgātō clārā pecūniam dant.
Malī servī equum bonum Mārcī dominī necant.
Galba agricola et Iūlia fīlia bona labōrant.
Mārcus nauta in īnsulā Siciliā habitat.
The wicked farmer is hastening to the village with (his) booty.
answer1: Agricola malus ad oppidum cum praedia properat.

content: Why does Galba’s daughter give arms and weapons to the wicked farmer?
answer1: Cur filia Galbae arma agricolae malo dat?

content: The good sailors are hastening to the toilsome battle.
answer1: Nautae boni ad pugnam duram properant.

content: The horses of the wicked farmers are small.
Lesbia invites the good sailor to dinner.
The Roman people give money to the good sailors.
Whose friends are fighting with the wicked farmers?
Friends care for the good sailors.
The reputation of the wicked farmer is not good.
Why is Lesbia with the good sailor hastening from the cottage?
Sextus cum nautā bonō praedam portat.
Ubi, nauta bone, sunt anna et tēla lēgātī Rōmānī?
Cūr, nautae bonī, malī agricolae ad Rhēnum properant? 1
Malī agricolae cum bonīs nautīs pugnant.
Frūmentum bonae terrae, gladī malī, bellī longī.
Cōnstantia magna, praesidia magna, clāre Vergi´lī.
Male serve, Ō clārum oppidum, male fīlī, fīliī malī, fīlī malī.
Fluvī longī, fluviī longī, fluviōrum longōrum, fāma praesi´dī magnī.
Cum gladiīs parvīs, cum deābus clārīs, ad nautās clārōs.
Multōrum proeliōrum, praedae magnae, ad proelia dūra.

Germānia, patria Germānōrum, est clāra terra. In Germāniā sunt fluviī multī. Rhēnus magnus et lātus fluvius Germāniae est. In silvīs lātīs Germāniae sunt ferae multae. Multi Germānii in oppidīs magnis et in vīcīs parvīs habitant et multī sunt agricolae bonī. Bella Germānōrum sunt magna et clāra. Populus Germāniae bellum et proelia amat et saepe cum finitimīs pugnat. Fluvius Rhēnus est fīnitimus oppidīs multīs et clārīs.

Magna est Italiae fāma, patriae Rōmānōrum, et clāra est Rōma, domina orbis terrārum. fluvium Rōmānum, quis nōn laudat et pulchrōs fluviō fīnitimōs agrōs? Altōs mūrōs, longa et dūra bella, clārās victōriās quis nōn laudat? Pulchra est terra Italia. Agrī bonī agricolīs praemia dant magna, et equī agricolārum cōpiam frūmentī ad oppida et vīcōs portant. In agrīs populī Rōmānī labōrant multī servī. Viae Italiae sunt longae et lātae. Fīnitima Italiae est īnsula Sicilia.
Ubi est, Mārce, fīlius tuus? Estne in pulchrā terrā Italiā?
Nōn est, Cornēlī, in Italiā. Ad fluvium Rhēnum properat cum cōpiīs Rōmānīs quia est4 fāma Novī bellī cum Germānīs. Līber Germāniae populus Rōmānōs Nōn amat.
Estne fīlius tuus copiārum Rōmānārum lēgātus?
Lēgātus nōn est, sed est apud legiōnāriōs.
Scūtum magnum et lōrīcam dūram et galeam pulchram portat.
Amat, et saepe fīliō meō praemia pulchra et praedam multam dat.
Terra Germānōrum, Cornēlī est fīnitima Rhēnō, fluviō magnō et altō.
Magna est Italiae fāma, patriae Rōmānōrum, et clāra est Rōma, domina orbis terrārum.
Tiberim,fluvium Rōmānum, quis nōn laudat et pulchrōs fluviō fīnitimōs agrōs?
Altōs mūrōs, longa et dūra bella, clārās victōriās quis nōn laudat?
Agrī bonī agricolīs praemia dant magna, et equī agricolārum cōpiam frūmentī ad oppida et vīcōs portant.
In agrīs populī Rōmānī labōrant multī servī.
Viae Italiae sunt longae et lātae.
